Process Analysis and Control

An insurance company could start its process improvement initiative with this question: How can we increase value to our customers? Then the company should evaluate the existing process to see how it aligns with the company’s goals.

 

Analyzing Processes

Process analysis is a systemic evaluation of all aspects of a process to make the process faster, more efficient, less expensive, and more focused on the customer. Given the variety of techniques for process analysis, process teams should identify the technique most likely to help them achieve their goals.

Thorough analysis of a business process requires, at least, a process map to determine which activities are impeding success. Companies can also use swim lane diagrams, which elaborate on simple process maps by identifying the parties responsible for each activity. Additionally, companies can use value stream maps, which are visual representations of processes that identify each activity’s end value to the customer.

Value stream maps help identify the parts of a process that are not adding value to the customer, or that are slowing down the continuous flow process of value creation known as a value stream. People can use value streams to study how materials and information flow through a current process. A value stream is different from a value chain, in part because a value chain focuses on organizational functions, whereas a value stream usually focuses on cross-functional processes.

Process analysis requires evaluating processes to determine the effectiveness of existing resources (called resource analysis) and the efficiency of workflow (called workflow analysis). Managers can use the results of a process analysis to control ongoing processes, identify training opportunities, or make decisions about whether to keep the process.

 

Controlling Processes

After analyzing a process for deficiencies, decision makers should seek to control those deficiencies by measuring performance in line with specific goals. Benchmarks and key performance indicators can serve as measurements of how well a process is working.

Benchmarking is a formal program for measuring company performance results, identifying best practices for the same performance areas, and emulating best practices for company processes. A benchmark is a performance standard that a company aspires to achieve. To identify appropriate benchmarks, companies often look at industry benchmarks—high performance standards achieved by other companies in their same industry—or at universal benchmarks—positive results achieved by another company performing the same process, regardless of industry. Companies can also use previous internal results as benchmarks. Managers should review benchmarks at periodic intervals and make updates that reflect changing needs.

EXAMPLE

Analysts at Raylite Insurance Company gathered information about the time required for underwriting and policy issue. They supplemented this information with validated, public industry data from a benchmarking study of several comparable companies with similar products and markets.

After averaging these companies’ new business turnaround times, the analysts found that they were exceeding the turnaround time benchmarks by an average of two weeks. The employees concluded that the company takes longer than necessary to issue policies, and should look for ways to streamline the new business process.

Recall that a key performance indicator (KPI) is a measure of a key process outcome. Executive-level managers use KPIs as an indication of company performance relative to a strategic goal. KPIs help companies identify gaps between what customers need and what the company offers.

EXAMPLE

From customer surveys, Crystal Insurance Company learns that customers want their requests handled more quickly. Crystal Insurance Company uses a contact center display, similar to the one in Figure 4.2 that displays the number of callers on hold, the longest current hold time, and the percentage of calls answered within a specific number of seconds. Managers can use this information to generate reports on specific measures, like timeliness. Then managers can use the numbers in these reports as KPIs to determine which part of the customer service process needs attention.

 

A company might also use KPIs to implement a balanced scorecard approach. The balanced scorecard approach relies on two types of graphic displays—balanced scorecards and dashboards, the latter of which are discussed later in the text—that give decision makers actionable information about the progress of operations.

A balanced scorecard displays a set of KPIs and compares the values to performance standards. It provides a comprehensive overview of the alignment of organizational perspectives with organizational goals. A typical balanced scorecard keeps track of a company’s activities in terms of four perspectives. In some cases, each perspective has a comprehensive list of objectives beneath it. The four perspectives are largely constant from one company to the next, though the details and definitions vary. Figure 4.3 summarizes the four perspectives.

If a company finds that data from any one of its four perspectives fails to meet corporate goals, the company should pursue process improvements. The examples below address unmet goals from each of the four perspectives.

EXAMPLES

Financial Performance

Managers at Raylite Insurance Company learn that they can improve upon financial performance by implementing better financial tracking processes.

They decide to provide company executives with virtual alerts so that the executives can respond immediately to deviations.

Customer Satisfaction

Occasionally, customers of Crystal Insurance indicate dissatisfaction with resolution speed. Decision makers at Crystal hope to increase the timeliness of customer service interactions.

After each completed interaction, the system offers a survey asking customers to rate their satisfaction with how quickly the representative solved their problem. At the end of each quarter, decision makers look at the percentage of interactions with customers who were “extremely satisfied” with the timeliness of the resolution. To explore customer satisfaction over time, they compare the new percentage to percentages from previous quarters.

Internal Operations

Raylite’s process for issuing new policies involves several manual interventions.

Linda Luongo, Raylite’s process improvement specialist, decides that Raylite can reduce the manual labor involved by automating several of the steps.

Learning and Growth

John Green, a manager at Crystal Insurance Company, studies customer call logs. He learns that customer service representatives have trouble helping customers who call in with questions about the new website.

John decides to hold more comprehensive employee training sessions on using the new website.

 

Methods of Process Improvement

Once decision makers decide which process needs improvement, they can decide on the method of action to fix the causes behind the inefficiencies. In many cases, incremental improvements are enough to fine-tune the process so that it accomplishes desired results.

EXAMPLE

EndiFirst sees declining performance in the perspective of customer satisfaction since rolling out their new self-service portal. Lately, customers such as Maya respond to surveys with complaints about error messages, the number of steps to complete a transaction, and the inability of customer service representatives to answer questions about transaction issues.

Decision makers at EndiFirst decide they need to improve the speed, accuracy, and ease of self-service portal transactions.

EndiFirst’s self-service portal does not seem to be working well. However, companies should continue to improve processes and increase value to customers even if processes run smoothly. Continuous process improvement uses strategic initiatives to make ongoing, incremental improvements in processes and technology. Continuous process improvement assigns accountability and provides a framework for incremental decisions. It forces team members to focus on a key process for meeting customer needs.

Many methodologies exist for continuous process improvement. Using these methodologies, companies see improvements in customer experience, employee satisfaction, speed-to-market, expense reduction, and overall market position. 2 Among the most common methodologies are kaizen, Lean management, Six Sigma, Lean Six Sigma, and agile management.

 

Kaizen

Kaizen is a gradual and continuous approach to process improvement using a series of modest changes and feedback from process team members. Historically, kaizen is a Japanese way-of-life philosophy that holds that every aspect of a life should be continually improved. 3 In business applications of kaizen, teams of workers apply the principles of this philosophy to their work through small process adjustments.

The application of kaizen in business relies on five principles and three key values. We can summarize the five principles of kaizen as teamwork, quality control, personal discipline, improved morale, and suggestions for improvement. We can summarize the three key values or factors of kaizen as elimination of waste, good housekeeping, and standardization.

EXAMPLE

Members of the process team at Crystal Insurance conduct closure debriefings with executives after every process implementation. Based on lessons learned, they tweak their process design strategy to move it further away from the problem points of the most recent implementation. As a result, the team improves standardization and efficiency with each meeting.

 

For kaizen to work, companies need to create open communication at every level. This can challenge companies whose employees do not often work collaboratively or share ideas. In addition, kaizen does not lead to immediate results. Companies using kaizen need to help employees think in terms of the big picture, which sometimes meets resistance.

Despite drawbacks, kaizen process improvements tend to be simple and inexpensive to implement. This simplicity makes kaizen a useful addition to other process improvement approaches, such as Lean management.

 

Lean Management

Lean management is a continuous process improvement approach that emphasizes creating a value stream comprising Lean processes with minimal waste. (In most sources, the “L” in the word “Lean,” considered a proper noun, is capitalized.) According to this methodology, the biggest opportunity for process improvement comes from identifying and eliminating waste, thereby creating value streams. Lean management promotes five main principles and reduces seven wastes, as follows:

 

Five Lean

Seven Wastes of Lean

•  Define value from the perspective of the customer

•  Identify the value stream

•  Create a continuous flow of value-adding steps

•  Allow processes to respond to the pull of the customer

•  Pursue perfection

•  Overproduction

•  Defects

•  Unnecessary inventory

•  Inappropriate processing

•  Excessive transportation

•  Waiting

•  Excessive motion

Lean thinking places less emphasis on optimizing individual activities and more emphasis on optimizing the cross-departmental, continuous flow of entire processes. Eliminating waste across value streams requires fewer resources than eliminating waste at certain points.

Lean principles apply to the insurance industry in terms of seeking to understand customer needs, identifying the value stream in a process, implementing a continuous flow, maintaining clear communication, improving speed, and eliminating handoffs. Lean principles can also apply directly to policy issue and updates to customer information.

Lean management emphasizes the use of technology in order to reduce time and expense. For instance, one way to make processes leaner is by eliminating handoffs. A handoff is a transfer of work from one work team member to another, typically across organizational boundaries. To eliminate handoffs, many insurers use straight-through processing (STP), which refers to a fully automated process in which the steps in a specified transaction type are conducted without human intervention. A company new to STP might have to invest in new technology.

EXAMPLE

Using STP, an agent can submit an application electronically. When the application appears in the system, the system can automatically conduct all of the required processing steps, issue the contract to the customer, and arrange the commission payment to the agent without any manual intervention.

Since Lean principles recommend maintaining a continuous flow, applying the principles to a financial services process requires either stabilizing the flow of inputs or increasing capacity. As a result, making existing processes Lean calls for considerable effort over a long period. The ultimate results of Lean management, however, are smoother processes, reduced need for resources, and improved employee morale.

Most Lean management practices apply to manufacturing processes. Therefore, financial services companies typically combine it with other process improvement techniques.

 

Six Sigma

Six Sigma is a disciplined approach for defining, measuring, analyzing, improving, and controlling quality by reducing process defects so that results fall within established parameters. A defect refers to anything that produces waste. Sigma is a measure of how close performance is to specifications. Six refers to the possible performance levels a company can achieve. Sigma levels range from one (significant defects) to six (minimal defects). Despite its origin in manufacturing, many companies in the service sector employ Six Sigma successfully.

Insurance companies use Six Sigma to identify and eliminate defects such as those that result in

  • Difficulty in accessing or navigating a company website

  • Improper denial of insurance claims

  • Denial of coverage for a proposed insured who should have been covered or provision of coverage for a proposed insured who should have been denied

  • Failure to process client transactions correctly

  • Failure to meet regulatory requirements related to product advertising or claim investigation

  • Submission of insurance applications that contain incomplete or incorrect information

Six Sigma programs use terms derived from the martial arts to describe team member status, and levels range from master black belts to yellow belts. In this hierarchy, some individuals spend more time on the initiative than others do. Insurance companies that implement Six Sigma programs can train their employees to be Six Sigma team members. Alternatively, they can employ outside vendors who specialize in Six Sigma to establish programs and train employees. Figure 4.4 illustrates Six Sigma team roles.

Six Sigma teams can use an approach called root-cause analysis to identify the cause of process failures. Root-cause analysis (RCA) is a set of problem-solving methods and tools designed to determine the actual causal factors that led to a particular incident or result. Unlike other statistical tools, which ask “What?” and “How?” RCA focuses on “Why?” and directs users to continue to ask questions until they identify the root cause of a problem. In addition to being specific and identifiable, a root cause must fall under the company’s control and be capable of reasonable remedy or resolution. Regarding its self-service transactions, EndiFirst might ask:

  • Why are customers dissatisfied with the self-service portal? The portal often directs users to call customer service upon submission of a transaction.

  • Why do customers need to call customer service? The submission often results in an error message.

  • Why are customers receiving error messages? There seems to be a glitch causing the portal to time out unpredictably. On reload—whether or not the payment goes through—the system provides an error message.

  • Why does the system have glitches? Not all components of the portal received the same thorough testing.

  • Why weren’t some components tested thoroughly? The update took longer than anticipated. In order to introduce the update on schedule, developers had to forgo some final tests.

  • Why did the developers run out of time? The three software developers at EndiFirst were working on several projects at once with similar completion dates.

The answer to the team’s last question helped identify one cause of the process inefficiency. EndiFirst’s development team was working on several projects at once, and there were too few developers for the number of tasks. To ensure better systems going forward, EndiFirst might consider hiring more developers so that they have the resources for careful testing and implementation.

If a process is inefficient on more than one level, there can be many root causes. For instance, EndiFirst developers might need more training on best practices to reduce the likelihood of future glitches. EndiFirst customer service representatives might need training on how to interact with the portal, so that customers get consistent information through both communication channels. Before making changes like these, however, EndiFirst should analyze and model the effects of these changes on budgeting, scheduling, and job structure.

When used correctly, Six Sigma results in measurable improvements. However, Six Sigma requires a lot of support from management to be successful and often results in high upfront costs for training or outside expertise. Six Sigma also relies on extensive data, which can be difficult and time-consuming to collect. Finally, Six Sigma does not work for every functional area or project. It isn’t ideal for nonstandard processes with unclear defects, for example.

 

Lean Six Sigma

Many companies experience positive results 4 when they combine Lean management principles with those of Six Sigma to create a hybrid quality improvement method known as Lean Six Sigma. The Lean part of this approach applies the philosophical view of efficiency. Its focus is on better serving customers’ needs by removing processes that create waste. The Six Sigma part of the approach requires using rigorous analytical approaches to quantify hidden instances of waste. Its focus is on continually improving processes that add value for the customer.

EXAMPLE

Paradise Insurance employees are encouraged to save time by streamlining tasks with technology and conducting brief check-ins instead of having frequent planned meetings.

A group of Paradise Insurance employees received training to achieve the Six Sigma status of green belt. In addition to the business-wide time-saving initiative, the group feels empowered to identify and address process defects.

Because Lean Six Sigma combines two distinct approaches to waste elimination, it often requires twice the analysis. However, a company that uses a tailored combination of tools from Lean and Six Sigma has more tools available than a company that uses just one of these approaches.

 

Agile Management and Organizational Agility

Agile management is an approach to business effectiveness focused on finding and seizing opportunities to improve operations and processes. Agile management requires employees to develop a growth mindset that emphasizes both the incompleteness of existing knowledge and the importance of continuous learning. The agile outlook fits with other continuous process improvement approaches because agile management emphasizes the benefits that companies expect from constantly improving their operational efficiency and rethinking customer needs.

Agile management supports employee empowerment, helping employees at every organizational level gain comfort with change and decision-making. Organizational agilityis an organization’s ability to adapt quickly to changes in the external environment. Organizational agility is especially important when the pace of environmental change is great.

EXAMPLE

During product development, Raylite Insurance uses a live, collaborative document that employees update with examples of lessons learned. The document empowers the team to make and keep track of real-time adjustments to ongoing projects. This fluid approach to continuous improvement makes it easier to adapt to change and manage several projects at once.

Technology helps address environmental change, and companies often use agile methodology when developing their information systems. A common agile approach is scrum—a framework for managing the processes involved in software development. Scrum teams typically break their processes into micro-activities called sprints, monitor progress, and adjust plans daily to address change. Scrum teams consist of the product owner, various team members, and a scrum master, who facilitates the team by managing all of the business processes required for software development. 5 Scrum is practical for software used in the current insurance industry climate, where new regulatory, actuarial, and technological considerations surface daily.

Agile management supports traits that increase efficiency: up-to-date schedules, fast turnaround times, and constant feedback. On the other hand, agile management’s frequent redirection demands more energy from employees, produces less complete documentation, and can make it challenging to measure overall progress toward a large goal. However, due to its success in handling multiple moving parts, agile management is a popular approach to project management.

 

Process Review

After the implementation of a process improvement, members of a process team conduct periodic review and assessment meetings to measure performance. Process review is the iterative, or cyclic, evaluation of an existing business process to find opportunities for improvement.

In the case of EndiFirst’s process improvement, the company needs to ensure at least the following outcomes on a regular basis:

  • Developers, including new hires, test all changes to the portal extensively

  • Customers experience few, if any, system errors

  • Representatives understand the system and know about all updates that can affect customer experience

As process teams identify opportunities for improvement, they should repeat the steps from Video 4.1:

Step 1: Define a key process.

Step 2: Map the process.

Step 3: Identify problems in the existing process using analysis and control.

Step 4: Implement process improvement.

Step 5: Review process improvement.

pages.title: Business Process Reengineering
pages.contents:
Business Process Reengineering

Sometimes companies might need to discard existing business processes and develop better ones. To transform operations or avoid recurring problems, or when the survival of the company depends on fundamental change, companies can use business process reengineering. Business process reengineering (BPR) is a formal program for fundamentally redesigning business processes, structures, and software with the goal of substantially improving cost, quality, service levels, and speed. For reengineering to be justified, it should lead to significantly better, faster, or less expensive operations.

To reengineer a business process, decision makers begin with an “as is” analysis. During this analysis, they identify which processes to discontinue and which, if any, to maintain. Then decision makers follow a series of steps similar to the steps of process improvement.

The difference between continuous process improvement and BPR is a matter of scope. Continuous process improvement involves incremental change, whereas BPR advocates major—if not total—reinvention. 6 Instead of working with an existing process and finding ways to make it better, BPR eliminates the existing process and begins anew. In some cases, companies completely reorganize departments into cross-functional teams, rethink company values, reassign responsibilities, and develop new information systems.

BPR involves greater operational risk than does continuous process improvement. Therefore, implementation of the new design should consist of significant analysis, simulation, prototyping, and training. After implementation, team members review the process by monitoring benchmarks and KPIs. Employee and customer attitudes toward the new design are prime indicators of performance.

EXAMPLE

Raylite Insurance Company’s new business numbers were in decline for almost 10 years. The insurer decided to address growing customer complaints about its “old-fashioned” approach to policy issue and maintenance.

Raylite reimagined its business to focus on increasing access to and ease of application. The company organized the ability to offer nonmedical underwriting directly through its website, a process in which examination-based proof of medical insurability is not required from a proposed insured. Instead of medical evaluations, Raylite would use the application, phone interviews with customers, and external sources such as online medical records to make its underwriting decisions.

After extensive preparation, the process team rolled out plans for reengineering. The company would develop a new website, place a new emphasis upon driving traffic to its website, and implement trainings on improving customer experience. The company would also invest in an intelligent underwriting system, which is software that performs underwriting steps based on preprogrammed rules and parses language to assess risk automatically.

The result of the reengineering initiative was greater traffic, fewer underwriting mistakes, and more time for the company to focus on improving business processes. The initiative also increased the number of completed applications. Survey results indicated that the new process improved employee morale.

Over time, as revenue increased and the need for manual labor decreased, Raylite realized substantial cost savings. The savings allowed the company to devote additional resources toward enhancing the customer experience even further.

An effective business process reengineering undertaking

  • Considers the customer first

  • Aims to increase the speed of an activity

  • Aims to reduce the cost of an activity

  • Eliminates processes known to produce a high rate of errors

  • Consolidates similar activities into one process, in part by eliminating handoffs

  • Acknowledges and, if possible, accommodates the preferences of employees and process team members

  • Designs with the awareness that humans are fallible and a process will not always conform to the plan, an approach called mistake-proofing (also known as fail-safe design)

  • Implements new processes only after thorough testing

  • Offers training on new processes as necessary

  • Automates processes to the extent possible

pages.title: Process Automation
pages.contents:
Process Automation

For peak efficiency, companies automate processes as much as they can. Information technology (IT)is the use of computer systems to gather, record, manage, analyze, and transmit company information. Automation helps to reduce the costs associated with slow response times, excess paperwork, document storage, and reporting errors. The result is higher-quality customer service, greater access to information, and increased opportunities to evaluate and improve company performance.

 

Cybersecurity

Companies today might not have to buy as much IT infrastructure as in the past because they can store their information in the cloud—a virtual data storage system that maintains digital data on multiple connected servers owned and managed by a hosting company. This advantage has a caveat, however: companies must still be able to secure their data. For greater control and visibility, many insurance companies still keep much of their information in-house.

Cyber breaches damage an insurance company’s reputation. Moreover, laws in most jurisdictions require insurance companies to take action to prevent the loss or corruption of customers’ nonpublic personal information. Most insurance companies are also required to protect proprietary information about the company itself. The insight below describes some regulations that apply to the insurance industry.

INSIGHT

The Regulation of Nonpublic Personal Information

At the federal level, the Gramm-Leach-Bliley (GLB) Act requires financial services companies operating in the United States to protect the security and confidentiality of customers’ nonpublic personal information.

At the state level, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners’ (NAIC’s) Model Privacy Act establishes standards that insurers operating in the United States must follow when collecting, using, and disclosing personal information related to insurance transactions.

The Health Information Technology for Electronic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act, signed into law in 2009, addresses privacy and security issues associated with the electronic transmission of protected health information.

Similar regulations exist in other countries. For example, the Canadian provinces of Quebec, British Columbia, and Alberta have laws regulating how private-sector organizations can collect, use, and disclose personal information. Other Canadian provinces are governed by similar federal requirements in the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA).

Methods for controlling against security risks include the use of

  • Intranets, which are private networks accessible only to people within an organization

  • Extranets, which are limited-access networks that allow people within the organization, and select external stakeholders, to access company information

  • Virtual private networks, which are systems that provide private access to authorized users who are not on location

  • Firewalls, which are system components designed to prevent unauthorized access to a network

  • Intrusion detection software, which is technology that monitors system traffic and alerts administrators to potential security issues

Companies can also require administrative sign-offs on system changes or implement security awareness programs to help minimize risks. United States law requires companies to have critically tested disaster recovery plans in place. 7 Disaster recovery plans mitigate risk in the case of uncontrollable circumstances such as extended power outages.

 

Integrated Business Process Management

To support management and automation, most companies use business process management systems. Although systems differ somewhat, they typically provide process modeling tools for analysis; developer tools for system integration; dashboards for measuring, monitoring, and control; and user interaction to facilitate work.

Business process management systems typically rely on rules engines . Rules enginesare software-based repositories of key business process rules that can be consistently applied in specified circumstances to produce the desired results. These programmed rules are the basis for automation. Rules engines require frequent review by IT based on business experience, feedback, and new findings. The insight below provides examples of business process management systems and their functions.

INSIGHT

Types of Business Process Management Systems

Customer experience management systems manage all aspects of company interactions with and knowledge of each customer. Each interaction with a customer generates data—on demographics, behavior, satisfaction level, and more—that insurers can compile into profiles used to build long-term relationships, evaluate risk, and identify product needs.

Automated workflow systems support business process control by coordinating the flow of documents between process steps. These systems automatically prioritize, schedule, distribute, trigger, and even complete certain process steps.

Queueing management systems model and analyze the work processes affected by waiting lines and establish rules for automatically routing items to service destinations. Insurers often use the information they gather from queueing management systems to measure the impact of volume changes on turnaround times or staffing needs.

Financial management systems keep track of income, expenses, and assets. They coordinate invoices, payments due and processed, and the security of payment information. They also provide decision makers with real-time, comprehensive access to financial information.

Revenue management systems apply models and measurements to predict how certain business decisions or market trends will affect company revenue.

Knowledge management systems gather, evaluate, and share a company’s information assets. They combine all of a company’s information resources and make that accumulated knowledge available to decision makers. Many insurers use knowledge management systems to give customer service representatives the information they need to answer customer questions.

Document management systems manage electronic documents by centralizing and organizing document storage, controlling access to documents, automating routines for archiving, and ensuring regulatory compliance with records retention and privacy requirement.

Content management systems manage and store electronic content, including graphics and videos.

 

Artificial Intelligence

We can expect technology use in the insurance industry to increase, fueling customers’ and companies’ expectations for self-service, mobile access, and personalization. 8 To remain ahead of disruption from insurance companies as well as other participants moving into the insurance market, insurers should keep up with digital trends.

Artificial intelligence, introduced in Chapter 1, refers to the growing area of computer science that emphasizes the development of intelligent machines that work, learn, and react like humans. AI involves machine learning, which allows computers to identify patterns without being expressly told where or how to find them. AI has important implications for business process improvement in the insurance industry. For example, computers today can learn to categorize the severity of vehicle damage after an accident to help evaluate car insurance claims. 9

AI can also make better use of data by analyzing the same data in different ways across business units. From customer experience management system data, an analyst can draw conclusions about both contact center initiatives and the company’s IT capabilities. Advanced AI can figure out and carry out both of these uses at once, allowing insurers more time for value-adding activities. The following insight summarizes some of the growing uses of AI in the insurance industry.

INSIGHT

Uses of AI in the Insurance Industry

Insurance companies can use AI to

  • Facilitate new product design through a reduced need for manual labor
  • Identify multiple uses for the same data
  • Find and address process errors before customers do
  • Offer personalized self-service options to streamline customer experience
  • Perform intelligent and nonmedical underwriting
  • Monitor behavior patterns to detect and prevent fraud
  • Recommend coaching steps for agents based on sales performance
  • Model life events to recommend products to customers
  • Acquire data from the internet of things (wherein everyday items such as cars access the internet) to enhance the data that guides process design
  • Communicate with customers as chatbots that transfer issues to humans after reaching their capacity to help

Much of today’s automation involves some element of AI. However, business processes in the near future are likely to involve even more, making efficient and effective processes easier to achieve.

The Project Lifecycle

  • Project Execution

  • Project Closure

Project Portfolio Management

The effort to redesign EndiFirst’s self-service portal, our example from Chapter 4, was a project initiated to improve a process. Unlike a process, which is an ongoing series of operations or work activities, a project is a temporary, planned undertaking to achieve a specified result. Project management is a framework for directing projects to completion that involves (1) setting project goals, and (2) planning, monitoring, and controlling project tasks, resources, and costs to meet those goals. Without project management, most projects would fail.

EXAMPLE

Project Management Need

Suppose you and your colleagues receive an assignment to work on a project developing a new product line. The unit manager briefs you and your colleagues on what the product should deliver and the expected completion date (“the end of the year”). Then, the unit manager leaves your group to perform the activities involved. She will check in on your group’s progress every few months.

The only clear goal is to deliver the product, but the steps involved are uncertain. With no formal schedule or budget, you and your colleagues don’t know which tasks to complete by when. You also don’t know which resources you need until you begin a task, meaning every task is put on hold until you acquire the necessary resource. With no formal meetings or status updates, changes go unaddressed until they cause issues.

When the unit manager reviews your group’s progress, she identifies incomplete steps and suggests that the team start over. Unfortunately, the group didn’t properly document each step. As a result, the group can expect to run into the same issues the second time around.

Effective project management would have minimized the issues in this example. However, ineffective project management is nearly as risky as no project management at all. A study by PwC reviewed over 10,000 projects from 200 companies in 30 countries and across multiple industries. They found that only 2.5 percent of companies successfully completed 100 percent of their projects. 1 Project failures cost companies money and offer customers no value, so companies need to prioritize project success. In the context of operational risk, project management is important because it allows companies to deliver optimal results, at the appropriate times, with the most efficient use of resources.

pages.title: Project Management
pages.contents:
Project Management Basics

At any given time, insurance companies have ongoing projects across operational areas. Examples of projects that an insurance company might undertake are

  • Developing new underwriting processes

  • Updating IT systems

  • Conducting a regulatory examination

  • Launching a new subsidiary

  • Creating a new marketing initiative

  • Improving a website design

  • Implementing a chatbot on the customer portal

 

Characteristics of a Project

Projects can vary widely in complexity and scope. For example, a company celebration would generally represent a low-complexity project with a narrow scope. On the other hand, a product development project would generally represent a high-complexity project with a broad scope.

Generally, the goal of a project is to either solve a problem (as in the case of reducing costs, responding to customer complaints, or accommodating industry change) or seize an opportunity (as in the case of growing product lines, expanding target markets, or investing in new technologies). In either case, projects implement the changes necessary to continue to deliver value to customers. A successful project typically has the following characteristics:

  • Clearly defined objectives

  • Constraints on resources, such as staff time, staff expertise, and funding

  • A beginning point and an ending point

  • A unique accomplishment that will signal the project’s completion

  • A team of dedicated individuals

  • Aspects that are likely to change over time, such as initial planning assumptions

  • Sequenced activities and events

Clearly defined objectives are perhaps the most important precursor to project success. When a project’s team members do not understand what the project is supposed to accomplish, the project is likely to fail.

 

The Project Manager’s Role

A project manager is the person who oversees the project team. A project manager is accountable for planning, organizing, directing, and controlling resources to achieve an established goal. Successful project management requires specialized skills, including both hard skills such as data management knowledge and soft skills such as communication abilities. In addition to guiding the individual components of a project to completion, project managers today have to

  • Understand the corporate mission and business needs. 2 A successful project manager understands the corporate mission and business needs. This person is also aware of both the internal and external circumstances that contribute to changing needs. Without such an understanding, the project manager might deliver a completed project that offers very little value to company stakeholders.

  • Cultivate a “project spirit.” Contributors to the learning library at the Project Management Institute (PMI), an organization that maintains a body of knowledge for the project management community, define project spirit as “the collective attitudes, emotions, and behavioral norms that are focused on the project’s expected outcome and achievements.” 3 A successful project manager knows how to motivate and lead a team. She constructs a vision that she uses to nurture enthusiasm about a project. She inspires employees to value the project as an essential contribution to the company’s mission.

  • Practice emotional intelligence. 4 A successful project manager knows how to manage emotions in the workplace. He has the interpersonal awareness to gain the support of stakeholders within the company and work with team members to achieve results. He can stay calm under pressure in order to collaborate across teams, negotiate changes, and address shortfalls and competing resource needs. He is also empathetic: he understands different employee working styles and the extenuating circumstances that can affect project completion.

  • Use technology effectively. 5 A successful project manager uses technology to streamline and standardize processes. She can access and use real-time data to keep track of a project’s direction. She stays up to date on industry regulations to ensure that the use of project management technology complies with regulations for security and privacy. If the project manager works with remote or partially remote teams, she can facilitate the virtual meetings and check-ins essential to project control.

  • Establish an ongoing knowledge base of project management standards. 6 A successful project manager is knowledgeable about best practices in project management and remains informed when standards change. The preeminent resource for project management standards is the Project Management Institute (PMI). The insight below describes some PMI publications.

INSIGHT

PMI Publications

pages.title: The Project Lifecycle
pages.contents:
The Project Lifecycle

We can think of project management as the application of management functions (planning, organizing, directing, and controlling) to all the phases within a project. A project phase is a segment of the project lifecycle consisting of a set of related project activities. A project lifecycle is the combination of all project phases, from project initiation to project closure. The phases are generally sequential in terms of when they begin, but can overlap. For example, successful project planning often continues through execution.

The name and number of project lifecycle phases vary among authorities. Companies use whatever model best fits their immediate needs. Many sources group the project lifecycle into four phases, as illustrated in Figure 5.1: an initiation phase, a planning phase, an execution phase, and a closure phase.

 

Project Initiation

The initiation phase of the project lifecycle consists of evaluating a proposed project to determine whether to proceed. During the initiation phase, stakeholders define the project’s purpose, review the project’s concept, and provide input on the project’s benefits and challenges. Project stakeholders are internal and external parties who have an interest in a project and expect to benefit from it.

EXAMPLES

Project Stakeholders

An employee whose duties are associated with the project

Members of a department that gains a new capability from a project

A customer who gains a new service as the result of a project

A vendor who sells services involved in completing the project

Obtaining initial stakeholder support is critical to a project’s success. However, the value of the project needs to be defined first.

 

Defining the Project’s Value

The question to answer during this step is, What’s the point of this project? Answering the question starts with identifying a project purpose. A project purpose is vague: it aligns broadly with the company mission, and describes why the project should be pursued. 7

EXAMPLE

Project Purpose

Deliver easy-to-access value to customers.

More specific than the purpose are project goals and objectives: they provide the boundaries for all future project-related activities. In other words, goals and objectives help create targets so that a team can turn an idea into a plan at a later stage. When it comes to projects, goals and objectives have different uses.

A project goal is a broad statement about what a project aims to accomplish in relation to business needs. Because the goal is such a high-level statement, it may require more than one project to achieve. Goals are important from a strategic standpoint because they tell the project manager what to work toward.

EXAMPLE

Project Goal

Improve EndiFirst’s online customer experience.

A project objective is a statement about how the company will accomplish the project goal. Good objectives should be SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, and Time-bound. 8 Objectives should also be concise: they should briefly describe actions needed to achieve the goal, but not go into detail about plans.

EXAMPLES

Project Objectives

Objective 1: Conduct three usability testing events and 1,000 customer surveys, and analyze results by January 20XX.

Objective 2: Provide developer training on best practices for portal development by March 20XX.

Objective 3: Redesign and test the self-service portal by August 20XX.

Objective 4: Provide IT and CSR training on best practices for portal support by September 20XX.

Objective 5: Launch self-service portal by October 20XX.

Purposes are established before goals because a goal without a purpose could result in a deviation from the overall mission. For instance, a project might improve the online experience for customers, but make it more difficult for customers to figure out how to access other communication channels.

Goals are established before objectives because an objective without a goal could result in completion of a project that does not add value. For example, a team could design a self-service portal that looks better and works faster but is not easier to use for customers.

Defining a project’s goals and objectives often requires research into the business problem. Managers can use this research to develop a business case.

 

Establishing a Business Case

A business case is a justification for a proposed project that highlights how a project’s benefits to the company will outweigh its costs and risks. Large or complex projects need a business case to convince the key decision maker that the project is worth pursuing.

The management responsible for the team or unit proposing the project usually develops the business case. Management can enlist the help of project managers, business analysts, team members, subject matter experts, or other relevant stakeholders to draft a case for presentation. Formats vary by organization, but will probably include information about

  • The reasons for pursuing the project

  • How the project contributes to the company mission and strategy

  • Existing research that supports the project

  • Different options considered and why they were or were not selected

  • Measurable benefits of pursuing the project

  • Risks and assumptions involved with pursuing the project

  • Expected cost and method of funding for the project

  • Timeframe for the project 9

Business cases for small projects might contain minimal information and only require manager approval. Business cases for complex projects might contain detailed information, such as action steps and cost breakdown per task. If the information used to develop the business case reveals issues with a project’s feasibility—that is, the degree to which company resources will be able to carry a project to completion—the business case should address those directly.

When the business case is complete, the person responsible presents it to one or more decision makers who can, based upon business needs, (1) accept the proposal to continue the project, (2) request modifications to the project goals or resources, or (3) reject pursuit of the project altogether.

 

Developing the Project Charter

Once a business case receives approval, the project takes its formal identity from either the project charter or a contractual agreement, depending on whether the project is internal or encompasses more than one business entity. For a project performed under contract by an external vendor, a contractual agreement covers rights and obligations. For an internal project, companies use project charters. A project charter is a document that formally authorizes the project to take place and appoints a project manager. A project charter identifies the business purpose of the project and grants appropriate authority to the project manager to move the project to the planning phase. Figure 5.2 offers an example of a project charter including some of the information a typical charter might contain.

 

Designating Team Members

The next step is to designate team members. In addition to a project manager, most projects include a project sponsor and a project team. A project sponsor is typically a company executive who authorizes the project, provides support and resources for the project, and communicates project information up the organizational chain of command. A project team consists of all project team members assigned to perform any portion of the project activities. An important type of project team is a product development team, which is a group that performs hands-on development of a new product.

A project team is temporary, and its members can be fluid. Appropriate team members have the skills and means required to accomplish the project’s objectives. To this end, project teams are often cross-functional. A cross-functional team consists of representatives from two or more work groups that perform related business activities across organizational boundaries. Members of a cross-functional team communicate regularly to make sure that each organizational unit is aware of the other’s activities.

EXAMPLE

Team Member Identification

Ruby, the project manager; Rich, the unit manager; and Anderson, a member of the customer service team, are discussing Anderson’s current projects to decide if a new project would work for his schedule.

EndiFirst hired Anderson after launching the original self-service portal. He has spent much of his employment at EndiFirst responding to calls about the online experience. Anderson also has experience performing analysis of customer surveys. Anderson would be a valuable team member because his skill set is a good match for some of the project objectives.

Many project teams have one or more core team members, assigned to perform a significant portion of project activities. The company defines what constitutes a core team member.

EXAMPLES

Core Team Members

—At EndiFirst Insurance, individuals assigned to perform at least 10% of the budgeted staff time for a project are core team members.

—At Foundation Financial, individuals assigned to perform at least 25% of the budgeted staff time for a project are core team members.

Companies often record the relationships for managing company projects in an org chart, short for organizational chart. An org chart is a hierarchically patterned array of boxes and lines depicting the formal lines of authority, responsibility, and communication in an organization. Figure 5.3 illustrates an org chart for one company’s project management efforts. In this hierarchy, the company has permanent project management elements consisting of an executive-level project management committee with a project management office and project management office staff.

Although projects are temporary, large insurance companies typically have a project management office (PMO) or project management unit with a permanent staff. Such companies maintain a pool of seasoned project staff and assign these people to successive projects. Among organizations with PMOs, half report having enterprise project management offices (EPMOs). 10 EPMOs operate at the strategic level by assessing risk and organizing resources in relation to the company mission. The number of EPMOs is growing; traditional PMOs don’t always receive the amount of enterprise-level support crucial for managing operational risk.

Because projects take place in many contexts, the overall organization of a project team can take a number of forms. For a given project, companies usually provide a structure consisting of at least a project sponsor, a project manager, and a project team. Companies with strong project management resources and activities often have more levels in their hierarchies than in the example in Figure 5.3.

Project Planning

Appointing a project team allows the project to move to the planning phase of the lifecycle, where the project manager can use information about team members’ resource, schedule, and training needs to help organize project details. In the planning phase, the project manager establishes boundaries for the project, determines needed resources, and develops a project plan document. Project managers typically spend most of their time in the planning phase. Project planning begins before project execution and continues to some extent throughout project execution.

 

Developing the Project Scope

Planning begins with a scope statement. A scope statement is a report that clearly states the limits on a project by specifying the project size, resources, limitations, and deliverables. A project deliverable is a measurable outcome from a project. The project manager, project sponsor, project team members, and other stakeholders can all contribute to the information in a scope statement.

To develop the boundaries for the information in the scope statement, it helps to establish baselines. A project baseline is a measurable starting point agreed upon by various stakeholders as performance standards for a project. Stakeholders usually establish performance standards for scope (scope baselines), time (schedule baselines), and cost (budget baselines) based on the results from past projects. A scope baseline defines the scale of the project and describes the deliverables needed from planning through closure. A schedule baseline is a general timeline that respects the needs of the project and the capabilities of company resources. A budget baseline is a reasonable estimate of project cost. Teams can use all three to develop accurate scope information.

Scope statements do not have a standard format. Instead, the format varies to suit the company and project. Typically, information presented in a project scope statement includes

  • Purpose, goals, and objectives

  • Deliverables

  • Staff requirements

  • Resource requirements

  • Timelines

  • Budget

  • Constraints

A project manager can document part of the timeline using a time requirements budget. A time requirements budget is a type of budget that shows calendar units of time—days, weeks, or months—and the expected amount of staff time required during each specified unit. During the execution phase, when actual times become available, the time requirements budget becomes useful for tracking exceptions. Project constraints are circumstances that place limitations on a project, and traditionally include scope, time, and cost. Each constraint assumes a different priority level within a project. Moreover, the importance of these three basic constraints differs from one project to another. One system for prioritizing constraints is to rank each of the constraint categories—scope (the characteristics of the deliverable), time, and cost—according to importance, using the labels driving constraint, middle constraint, and weak constraint. The table below offers an example of constraint ranking.

Most Important Least Important

Driving Constraint

Middle Constraint

Weak Constraint

The number-one priority and the driving force behind the success of the project. The project will fail if the team does not meet this constraint.

Lower priority than the driving constraint but more important than the weak constraint.

Lowest-priority constraint. Possibly the least important obstacle to project success, or the most flexible measure.

Example

When implementing the new training initiative, the training must adhere to the scope. If the training does not result in improvements to employees’ abilities to perform their duties, the initiative has failed.

Example

The training initiative should be complete by a certain date. The team can make minor tweaks as needed as long as the initiative meets its scope, but cannot be adjusted too much or put off indefinitely.

Example

The project manager expects the initiative to meet budget. However, the rewards expected from smooth implementation will offset the cost of the training. There is room for adjustment provided the training meets deliverables and time constraints.

For one project, time constraints might have the highest priority, whereas cost constraints might be more important on another project. The project manager needs to identify the constraints with the highest priorities so that adjustments can be made later as needed. For example, if time is the driving constraint and a project gets behind schedule, one viable solution would be to commit more resources to the project. On the other hand, if cost is the driving constraint and a project is likely to exceed expected costs, then scaling back the scope of the project might be necessary.

 

Classifying Activities and Events

With a developed scope, a project manager can pursue more detailed planning. Detailed project planning requires basic knowledge about the activities likely to occur during the project. Remember that an activity is one of a set of actions that, together, accomplish a goal.

EXAMPLES

Project Activities in an Insurance Company

—Developing required policy forms

—Purchasing new software

—Filing policy forms with regulators

—Conducting training for employees

—Developing surveys for customers

Project managers sometimes conduct an activity analysis to determine how the activities in a project relate. An activity analysis is a report that documents the expected tasks and estimated time for completing a given activity, based on observation of or interviews with an individual performing the activity.

The minimum time required to complete a project is the sum of the minimum durations for all project activities. Therefore, a minimum time for each major activity is necessary to create a schedule. Relationships between project activities help establish the order of the activities in the schedule. For this reason, scheduling requires a project manager to determine whether activities are independent or dependent.

  • Independent activities. Team members can complete some activities without regard to the status of any other activities. Pairs of activities that can progress concurrently with no change to resource needs are called independent activities.

EXAMPLE

Independent Activities

EndiFirst software developers can make an update to a website at the same time a manager conducts a training session on customer service. These activities do not rely on each other for completion.

  • Dependent activities. Some project activities must be completed before others can be started because the activity requires shared company resources, such as staffing or technology. These activities are called dependent activities—activities that cannot be started until other activities have been completed because the outputs from one activity are required inputs for another activity. For time-sensitive projects, some dependent activities can occur at the same time as long as one reaches a certain point—for instance, no longer needing a particular staff member—before the other begins.

EXAMPLE

Dependent Activities

The project team cannot use the voice of the customer to guide web design until after the analysis of usability testing and customer surveys.

The completion of an activity is an event. An event may also be a milestone—an important interim goal for a project.

EXAMPLES

Project Milestones in an Insurance Company

—Regulatory approval of a policy form

—The arrival of a shipment of printed material

—The arrival of an application for new business

—Obtaining agent licenses and appointments

—Securing corporate approval for new underwriting rules, guidelines, and risk classes for existing or new markets

—Gaining corporate approval for a new claim policy of offering death benefit payments in a choice of a lump-sum payment or various settlement options

 

Visual Tools for Project Planning

To help with planning, project managers can represent project needs visually. For example, to make it easier to establish baselines, some project managers use work breakdown structures. A work breakdown structure (WBS) is a graphical display of project elements that often includes an estimate of the labor effort required for each project activity. A detailed WBS might include the availability and cost for each required resource. An example of a basic WBS chart appears in Figure 5.4.

Another method for project visualization is a simple flow chart. A flow chartshows the systematic progression of a series of activities, using connecting lines and conventional symbols. Although flow charts can involve many levels of detail, a macro flow chart that shows the broadest view is often adequate for a simple project overview. Flow charts usually consist of

  • Ovals that represent starting and stopping points

  • Boxes that represent important activities

  • Diamonds that indicate yes/no decision points

  • Circles that represent a point at which the flow chart connects with another process

  • Arrows that represent the flow of a project

Figure 5.5 offers an example of a macro flow chart for a customer service improvement project.

To create a flowchart, a project manager needs to consider all the relevant activities and events in a particular project and determine their proper sequence. Flowcharts are effective planning tools for simple, short-term projects. However, flowcharts are not always practical for complex projects in which multiple activities take place at the same time. In addition, flowcharts don’t indicate the total amount of time necessary to complete individual activities and events. For a more detailed visualization that includes time estimates, a project manager can use Gantt charts and network models.

 

Gantt Charts

A Gantt chart is a graphical scheduling tool that separates projects into critical activities and plots starting and ending dates for each activity. Gantt chart software is widely available, but project managers can also create Gantt charts using Excel spreadsheets.

Gantt charts help users show dependencies among activities, assign staff to activities, define project milestones, and share information throughout the organization. The horizontal axis of a Gantt chart represents the total time span of the project broken into increments of days, weeks, or months. The vertical axis of a Gantt chart represents separate activities that make up the project. The graph area of the Gantt chart, known as the schedule timeframe, displays a stack of horizontal bars with one for each activity. The stack of bars fills in the time between the beginning and end of a project.

During a project, the Gantt chart display is updated regularly to indicate which activities have been completed and which remain to be performed. By showing the progress of activities, a Gantt chart helps companies determine if corrective action is needed as the project is under way. Figure 5.6 is a Gantt chart for a new product launch.

Gantt charts often incorporate the following information:

  • Project status refers to the project’s progress toward completion at a given point in time. A project manager can update a Gantt chart by extending the bar for each activity to a length proportional to the amount of work completed.

  • A milestone schedule, or master schedule, is a summary listing of major activities and key milestones. A project manager can incorporate milestones into a Gantt chart.

  • Some Gantt charts use initials, numbers, or colors to indicate which team member is responsible for each activity.

Specific types of Gantt charts include

  • A daily schedule Gantt chart, which displays a repeating daily schedule, such as a routine schedule for project update meetings. One example of a daily schedule Gantt chart is the function offered by most email clients for scheduling meetings.

  • A baseline Gantt chart, which is used as the starting point for a project plan. To highlight departures from the plan or budget, a baseline Gantt chart can be placed alongside another display that shows actual project progress.

  • A stoplight Gantt chart, which offers the typical Gantt chart display plus the added feature of a stoplight status column indicating progress for a given row. A green stoplight indicates that a row for an activity is on or ahead of schedule. A yellow (or amber) stoplight indicates that a project is perhaps not entirely on schedule, but has not met the criteria for intervention. A red stoplight indicates that a project is receiving corrective action from the project manager.11

EXAMPLE

The actual finish date for the development of EndiFirst’s training initiative fell on March 1, one month before the scheduled finish date. This stoplight status column is coded in green.

 

Estimating Time

For scheduling purposes, a project manager has to know the expected time, which is an estimate of the time needed to complete project activities. If an activity analysis provides the time requirements, then each activity only needs one expected time. If time requirements are untested, a project manager can use a weighted average of three time estimates: an optimistic time, a most probable time, and a pessimistic time.

  • Optimistic time, noted as to , is the shortest amount of time the activity is likely to require.

  • Most probable time, denoted as tm , is the amount of time that the activity is most likely to require.

  • Pessimistic time, denoted as tp , is the longest amount of time the activity is likely to require.

Using all three estimates above, a project manager can calculate the expected time, denoted as te . The expected time for an activity is a weighted average of the optimistic, most probable, and pessimistic times. It’s called the weighted average because the most probable time is given more weight than the other two less probable values. The equation for using a weighted average as the expected time for an activity can be expressed as

 

te = to + 4(tm) + tp
6

 

 

EXAMPLE

Suppose that the optimistic time for Activity A is 10 days, the most probable time for the activity is 16 days, and the pessimistic time is 20 days. Using the formula, the expected time to complete Activity A is 15.7 days:

te = 10 + (4 * 16) + 20

Network Models

Network models are useful to analyze a sequence of events and activities for project planning and project control purposes. A network model, sometimes referred to as a program evaluation and review technique (PERT) network, is a visual representation of the activities in a process or a project used to identify the best use of resources. Project managers can use network models to

  • Illustrate or map activities for an entire project.

  • Identify all the activities needed to complete the project on time.

  • Highlight activity sequences and relationships that are critical to successful project completion, and further, to illustrate the role of each activity within the entire project.

  • Specify details of the project in the planning phase for later analysis.

  • Support monitoring and controlling the project by providing a way to quickly identify deviations from the plan, the schedule, or (in some cases) the budget.

Network modeling software allows the user to create a chart of activities and events, estimate project costs, and display a schedule of activities for managing time and staffing needs. Depending on user preferences, most software can display the results as a chart, line diagram, or table.

Network models include, at a minimum, events, activities, times, network paths, and critical paths. A network path is a sequence of network activities from project inception to project end. A critical path is the most time-consuming chain of events in a network model. The critical path consists of the unique sequence of activities that, if delayed, would delay the entire project. Identifying the critical path is important because it highlights activities for which timely completion is crucial. A delay in an activity not on the critical path will not necessarily delay the project.

Steps for Finding a Project’s Critical Path:

  1. Divide the project elements into activities and events.
  2. Identify dependencies.
  3. Construct a network diagram to illustrate the required sequences of activities and events based on activity dependencies.
  4. Estimate the expected time for each activity, and enter the estimates onto the network diagram.
  5. Identify all alternative network paths from project start to finish.
  6. Calculate the sum of expected times for activities on each network path to determine the total expected time for completion of each alternative network path.
  7. Identify the network path with the longest expected time. This path is the critical path.

Figure 5.7 illustrates a simplified project network model for a new product launch. Circles symbolize project events, labeled A through N. Arrows symbolize project activities.

In the network model shown in Figure 5.7, there are four alternative paths through the network, along with the expected time needed to complete each one, as follows:

A network model can be used to identify the presence and amount of float in a project. Float, also known as slack time, is the length of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the entire project. Float helps with mistake-proofing project execution, such that if an activity is derailed, the work group has margin for getting it back on track.

No activity on the critical path can have float, but any other network activity can have float. To find the float in a network, subtract the expected time for each noncritical path from the expected time for the critical path. For events not on the critical path, network models typically show the latest allowable date for each event. The latest allowable date is the last date on which the event can occur without causing a delay in the project.

 

Project Schedules

A project manager can use information about baselines, activities, expected times, and networks to help establish comprehensive schedules, which provide information about the sequence and timing of events and how staff time should be allocated. A project schedule is a document that shows links between project elements, identifies dependencies, and shows a sequence that satisfies time and other constraints.

Some projects specify an early finish date and a late finish date, to allow for schedule variances. Generally, a schedule variance is the difference between the scheduled finish date for an activity and the actual finish date. Most members on a project team refer to the schedule to know when to complete activities. Figure 5.8 illustrates one type of project schedule.

 

Project Plan

A project plan is a comprehensive, formally executed document used to guide a project through closure. The primary uses of a project plan are to consolidate the information gathered throughout the initiation and planning phases and facilitate communication among stakeholders.

A project plan should document negotiated aspects of the project objectives, project performance standards relative to required outcomes, project schedule, project cost, and other resource requirements. A project plan is designed to be revised and updated as time passes and new information becomes available.

Keep in mind that projects differ in level of complexity and risk. The plan for a short, simple project can be informal. In this case, the plan could contain only a schedule and an executive summary, which is a concise overview of the project purpose. A more complex project plan might be a bound collection of related information and an appendix, with a table of contents like the one in Figure 5.9.

In a given network model, there are three alternative paths. The expected times needed to complete each network path are as follows: A-K-N is 42 days, A-C-O is 68 days, and A-J-P is 33 days. What is the float for network path A-K-N?

  1. 35 days
  2. 26 days
  3. 39 days

Check your answer

 

Project Execution

After authorization, team members can begin working on the project. The execution phase of project management consists of formally launching a project, communicating with team members, and progressing toward negotiated outcomes. The project team performs activities as scheduled during this phase.

An effective project team understands that issues will occur, that the planning process is ongoing, and that individual elements of a project will need adjustments over time. In other words, the project team has to remain agile to succeed.

As we mentioned in Chapter 4, agile management is an approach to business effectiveness focused on finding and seizing opportunities to improve operations. With agile project management, project components are analyzed, adjusted, and delivered as individual units. The ability to adjust along the way increases attention to, and improves the quality of, each project deliverable.

There is some controversy surrounding the feasibility of using an agile management style for complex projects. 12 However, as a testament to its name, a successful agile approach should be responsive to alterations based on level of complexity. In other words, even if the approach to a project is not purely agile, a project team can use agile thinking to help the project survive change.

EXAMPLE

Agile Approach

Ruby, the project manager at EndiFirst, updates the schedule based on her daily check-ins with team members. She can enter a change to an activity completion date, and the schedule will automatically update the total completion date according to the change made. Periodically, she revisits the total completion date in relation to project objectives. If needed, she negotiates adjustments to other activities to compensate for lost time.

 

Project Control

Because change is inevitable, project execution relies on project control. During project control, the project manager monitors progress and takes any corrective action in conjunction with members of the team. All aspects of a project are subject to project control.

To determine the status of activities, a project manager can conduct periodic meetings. A stand-up meeting is a meeting during which employees stand up as they offer summaries about their progress on an activity. The unintuitive feature of standing is intended to keep meetings short. (Not all companies use the term literally—in some cases, these status checks don’t require standing or are conducted virtually and still retain the name “stand-up meeting.”)

The project manager uses information about the status of activities to gauge project performance. Documents created in the planning phase serve as items for comparison. For example, the schedule can help a project manager compare expected dates to actual dates. A project manager also could revisit the time requirements budget to track exceptions as in the table below. Asterisks indicate the months when actual hours exceeded expected hours.
